instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_SO: What is PP5V_SO? PP5V_SO is a typo of PP5V_S0, which is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state. The person who typed PP5V_SO thought that the S0 in PP5V_S0 was SO, if you see PP5V_SO assume the user made a typo and meant to type PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message: Hi - Have board with liquid damage on DC In board and corrosion on upper right side of main board to the right of CPU. Replaced DC In board and everything was working. After cleaning now I get no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SO</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message: In Other News: Just plugged it back in and its working again. ???  Thanks in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message: Is there a light on the charger? Voltage on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message: update: Yes, light on charger. Its off and on again. Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message: And to answer your first question. No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message:
Does the board show any signs of life other then the charging light? Is there a fan spin?

How is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> doing?

Also I assume you've already cleaned up the corrosion on the upper right of the CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message: I bet pin 8 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is corroded.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message: Oh yea...there's life. The entire board will work fine. It even boots. Then I unplug charger and plug back in and it will be dead. Ill start probing around and all of a sudden it turns on again. I did clean the corrosion because I wrongfully assumed it was working but I know where the damage was. All other rails are good. I will check again tomorrow in the AM. Thanks for your responses guys. Have a good one!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message: Hi. Checked this morning around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. Getting 8.5 V in to pin 17. Nothing on pin 10 or pin 1.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message: No idea, this will be corrosion under somewhere. Only you saw where the corrosion was, I cannot help in this case. Simple fact is is the CPU power in not coming on all rails will start cycling and you should be able to see that on <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message: All set here. Thanks for your time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage
threads.message: Besides throwing dirty looks its way from across the room, no.
